bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Howard A. Kelly, March 22, 1905

div1.p: Agramonte writes about the responsibilities of the Yellow Fever Commission members, and gives a brief chronology of their activities.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Howard A. Kelly, March 22, 1905
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
Dr. Aristides Agramonte,
Profesor de Bacteriologia y Patologia Experimental,
Facultad de Medicina,
Universidad de la Habana, Cuba.
-----
March 22, 1905.
Howard A. Kelly, M. D.
Baltimore, Md.
My dear Sir;
div1.p:
Your kind note of the 13th inst. has reached me
after some delay.

It affords me great pleasure to learn that you are about to
mention the names of Major Reed's co-workers and give them some
credit in the final elucidation of the yellow fever problem, from
the sanitarian's standpoint.

To one of us, my fiiend friend and classmate Dr. Lazear, (car-
ried away by his scientific zeal at an early period of the invest-
igation) is due the greatest honor and glory; in fact, he it was
who produced the first case, (the soldier Dean,) unknown to the
others, and subsequently infected Carroll when the latter did not
as yet believe in such mosquito infection. It was after this demons-
tration that Lazear allowed himself to be bitten at “Las Animas”
Hospital and not until then was Major Reed communicated with, he
being at the time in Washington, as may be verified by the military
Order issued for his transfer to Cuba in those days.

At the time the Commission was appointed in 1900, we agreed
(2)
to work as follows: Maj. Reed was to direct the general work, Car-
rol to have charge of the bacteriologic investigation, Lazear the
mosquito work, having had training in this field, (the only member
of the Board at the time acquainted with the mosquito,) and I had
charge of autopsies and pathologic work. Maj. Reed went back to
Washington before Lazear produced the first case and returned as I
said above at the time of Lazear's death when we prepared our “Pre-
liminary Note” read by Maj. Reed at Indianapolis, at the meeting of
the American Public Health Association.

After that, the experimental station, “Camp Lazear” was esta-
blished and the more thorough work was then carried out by the re-
maining members, Drs. Reed, Carroll and myself.

This is a bit of inside history of the Board which I think
an honest historian ought to know; it deprives of no credit to any-
one and its publication will be the means of doing fair justice to
Dr. Lazear. The real value of his work in the Commission has not
been appreciated.

Drs. Stark, Ames, Kean, R.P.Cooke and others were at the time
of which I write living at Camp Columbia and took no little interest
in our work; they no doubt remember the circumstances surrounding
those days. The exact dates when Dean, Carroll and Lazear were in-
fected are set down in our papers and the presence or absence of
the members of the Board may be shown by the Orders issued at the
time.

On a separate page I send you some biographical notes relat-
ing to my humble personality. For whatever notice you may give them
I thank you most gratefully.

Should you think that I may serve you in any way I shall be
very pleased to reciprocate.
